content: Regular breast cancer screening is important because it can detect breast cancer early, even before symptoms appear. When breast cancer is detected early, it is more likely to be treated successfully, leading to better outcomes and higher survival rates. Even if you don't think you have a high risk of breast cancer, it's still important to get screened regularly as breast cancer can develop in anyone. Many women with breast cancer have no known risk factors. The American Cancer Society recommends that all women starting at age 45 receive yearly mammograms, and this frequency may change based on your age, health history or family history. It's always best to talk to your healthcare provider about your individual risk factors and screening recommendations.
